```{r}
proportion <- data.frame(
year = c(2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016),
proportion = c((sum(six_drug$PATWT)/sum(six_clean$PATWT))*1000, (sum(seven_drug$PATWT)/sum(seven_clean$PATWT))*1000, (sum(eight_drug$PATWT)/sum(eight_clean$PATWT))*1000, (sum(nine_drug$PATWT)/sum(nine_clean$PATWT))*1000, (sum(ten_drug$PATWT)/sum(ten_clean$PATWT))*1000, (sum(eleven_drug$PATWT)/sum(eleven_clean$PATWT))*1000, (sum(twelve_drug$PATWT)/sum(twelve_clean$PATWT))*1000, (sum(thirteen_drug$PATWT)/sum(thirteen_clean$PATWT))*1000, (sum(fourteen_drug$PATWT)/sum(fourteen_clean$PATWT))*1000, (sum(fifteen_drug$PATWT)/sum(fifteen_clean$PATWT))*1000, (sum(sixteen_drug$PATWT)/sum(sixteen_clean$PATWT))*1000))

pairwise <- proportion %>%
  select("proportion")

pairwise <- proportion %>%
  mutate(yes = proportion/100)

pairwise$no <- rep(1000,nrow(pairwise))

pairwise <- pairwise %>%
  mutate(yes = yes*1000)

pairwise <- pairwise %>%
  select(yes, no)

pairwise
```

pairwiseprop <- pairwise.prop.test(pairwise$yes, pairwise$no)
pairwiseprop
```

proptrend
```

```{r}
require(ggplot2)
ggplot(proportion, aes(x = year, y = proportion)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") + 
  ylab("Proportion of Patients") + 
  xlab("Year") 
  
scatter.smooth(x=proportion$year, y=proportion$proportion) +
  title(main="Opioid Prescriptions Per Capita")

write.csv(proportion, file = "proportion.csv")

ggplot(proportion, aes(x = year, y = proportion)) + geom_point() + 
             stat_smooth(method ="lm", se = FALSE)

ggplot(proportion, aes(x = year, y = proportion)) + geom_point() + 
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, formula = y ~  x + I(x^2) )

cor(proportion$year, proportion$proportion)

linearMod <- lm(yes ~ no, data=pairwise)
summary(linearMod)

# creating least-squares method for fitting a parametric line
M <- lm(proportion ~ year, dat = proportion)

# fitting a 2nd order polynomial
M2 <- lm(proportion ~ year + I(year^2) , dat = proportion)

# fit loess function
lo <- loess(proportion ~ year, proportion, span = 0.5, degree = 1)

# creating a residual dependence plot
proportion$residuals <- residuals(M)
ggplot(proportion, aes(x = year, y = residuals)) + geom_point() +
             stat_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, span = 1, 
                         method.args = list(degree = 1) )

# previous model had convex line, so creating the plot using the second degree polynomial
proportion$residuals2 <- residuals(M2)
ggplot(proportion, aes(x = year, y = residuals2)) + geom_point() +
               stat_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, span = 1, 
                           method.args = list(degree = 1) )

# second degree was good fit, but just checking if loess has an improvement
proportion$residuals3 <- residuals(lo)
ggplot(proportion, aes(x = year, y = residuals3)) + geom_point() +
               stat_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, span = 1, method.args = list(degree = 1) )

# using the second degree to create a spread location plot
sl2 <- data.frame( std.res = sqrt(abs(residuals(M2))), 
                   fit     = predict(M2))

ggplot(sl2, aes(x = fit, y  =std.res)) + geom_point() +
              stat_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, span = 1, 
                          method.args = list(degree = 1) )

ggplot(sl2, aes(x = fit, y = std.res)) + geom_point() +
              stat_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, span = 1.5, 
                          method.args = list(degree = 1) )

# checking residuals for normality
ggplot(proportion, aes(sample = residuals2)) + geom_qq(distribution = qnorm) +
  geom_qq_line(distribution = qnorm, col = "blue")

```
